column4: I have an old computer on which I have installed DOS, now I would like to install Xubuntu but the only way I could is by taking the HDD and plug it with a IDE-USB adapter to my laptop...I've tried to install directly on it with my laptop but then back in the old PC, it seems that the MBR cant be written by the way I proceed, so I guess I have to manual install Xubuntu into this HDD. But then, will the MBR written by my previous DOS install will be able to
point to a series of boot files and finally linux intalled files?
you cant just boot off of the install CD ?
so you boot off the live CD using the laptop and then point the installer to the USB device ?

yes thats what I already did, but it didnt work the first time so I guess the adapter messed up the process of writting the MBR somehow, or maybe ...wait I remember having MBR problem at this time...maybe now that its fixed I could try again..
yeah thats not going to work - the installer will write the MBR to the laptop HDD by default
you need to tell the installer where to write the MBR to, I believe thats an option in there somewhere (an advanced option)
ohh! yes I know that option...I think I just totaly forgot...or maybe i tried...but it worth to try ?again?
thanks, I try and come back after
if that doesn't work - mount it using a VM
ex. install virtual box on the laptop - point the VM to the USB thing as the HDD
I tried that already and got plenty of weird errors.. anyway..lets go back to method #1
yeah the VM thing ... not an easy option
oh wait...some very important stuf...if I run the installer with my laptop...
it will configure Xubuntu for a recent laptop and then in my Pentium
I think you should use that computer as a brick
